title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
1.1 Introduction
A database management system (DBMS) is a software application that interacts with users, applications, and the database itself to capture and analyze data. A DBMS provides a systematic way to create, retrieve, update, and manage data. It allows users to define, create, maintain, and control access to the database.
Why databases are important?:

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
Data Storage: Databases provide a structured way to store large amounts of data efficiently.
Data Retrieval: They allow for quick and easy retrieval of data using queries.
Data Integrity: Databases enforce data integrity and consistency through constraints and rules.
Data Security: They provide mechanisms for securing data and controlling access to it.
Data Sharing: Databases enable multiple users to access and share data simultaneously.
Data Backup and Recovery: They provide tools for backing up data and recovering it in case of failure.
Data Relationships: Databases allow for the establishment of relationships between different data entities, enabling complex data modeling.
Data Analysis: They support advanced data analysis and reporting capabilities.
Data Scalability: Databases can handle large volumes of data and can be scaled to accommodate growth.
Data Transactions: They support transactions, ensuring that data operations are completed successfully or rolled back in case of failure.
Data Standards: Databases adhere to industry standards, making it easier to integrate with other systems and applications.
Data Performance: They optimize data access and retrieval for better performance.
Data Maintenance: Databases provide tools for maintaining data quality and consistency over time.
Data Auditing: They support auditing and tracking of data changes for compliance and accountability.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.2 Why use a DBMS and not a spreadsheet/table?
text:
1.2 Why use a DBMS and not a spreadsheet/table?
Spreadsheets are great for small datasets and simple calculations, but they have limitations when it comes to handling large amounts of data, complex relationships, and multi-user access. A DBMS is designed to handle these challenges and provides a more robust solution for data management.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
1.3 Why not Excel?
Excel is a easy to use tool for data analysis and visualization, but it is not designed to be a full-fledged database management system. While Excel can be used for small datasets and simple calculations, a DBMS is a better choice for larger datasets and more complex data management needs. For example, in a large banking system, a DBMS would be used to manage customer accounts, transactions, and other data, while Excel might be used for simple reporting or analysis tasks. To deal with single large dataset, a DBMS is more efficient and effective than Excel. For example, a DBMS can handle millions of records and complex queries, while Excel may struggle with performance and data integrity issues. Also, when we need to joins multiple tables together, a DBMS provides powerful tools for managing relationships between tables, while Excel is limited in this regard. Imagine a bank store all the customers data in Excel, it would be very difficult to manage and retrieve the data efficiently. A DBMS would provide a more structured and efficient way to manage the data.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
1.5 What is Relational Database (RDBMS)?
A relational database is a type of database that organizes data into tables, which consist of rows and columns. Each table represents a specific entity or concept, and the columns represent the attributes or properties of that entity. The rows in the table represent individual records or instances of the entity. It allows for the establishment of relationships between different tables using keys, enabling complex data modeling and retrieval. Figure 1 illustrates a simple relational database with four tables: Drivers License, Member, Rental, Movie_Rental and Movie. Each table has its own set of columns and rows, and the relationships between the tables are established using primary and foreign keys. (we will cover keys later).



Figure 1: Simple Relational Database Example.


source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C3icLzBtg8I

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.6 What is the relationship between SQL vs.¬†DBMS?
text:
1.6 What is the relationship between SQL vs.¬†DBMS?
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases. It is the standard language for interacting with a DBMS. SQL allows users to create, read, update, and delete data in a database. A DBMS is the software that implements the database and provides the interface for users to interact with it using SQL.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.7 Why SQL is important for a data analyst?
text:
1.7 Why SQL is important for a data analyst?
SQL is important because it provides a standardized way to interact with relational databases. It allows users to perform complex queries, retrieve data, and manipulate data in a consistent manner. SQL is widely used in the industry and is supported by most relational database management systems (RDBMS). Learning SQL is essential for anyone working with databases, as it enables them to effectively manage and analyze data. Additionally, SQL skills are highly sought after in the job market, making it a valuable asset for data analysts.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.1 What is SQL?
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a standard programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases. It is used to perform various operations on the data stored in a database, such as querying, updating, inserting, and deleting data. SQL is widely used in the industry and is supported by most relational database management systems (RDBMS), including MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, and Microsoft SQL Server. The standard language for different RDBMS may have slight variations, but the core SQL syntax and functionality remain consistent across platforms. In this course, we will focus on using Oracle as our RDBMS. Oracle is chosen as it is widely used in the industry and provides a robust platform for learning SQL and database management concepts.
SQL is a declarative language, meaning that users specify what they want to do with the data, rather than how to do it. This allows for more efficient and optimized execution of queries by the database engine. SQL is also a powerful language that supports complex queries, joins, aggregations, and subqueries, making it suitable for a wide range of data analysis tasks.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.2 Basic SQL Commands
There are several types of SQL commands, each serving a different purpose. The main categories of SQL commands are:

Data Manipulation Language (DML): Used to manipulate data in the database.

Data Definition Language (DDL): Used to define and manage the structure of the database.

Data Query Language (DQL): Used to query and retrieve data from the database.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.3 Data Manipulation Language (DML)
DML commands are used to manipulate data in the database. They include commands for inserting, updating, deleting, and retrieving data.

INSERT: Used to add new rows of data to a table.
UPDATE: Used to modify existing data in a table.
DELETE: Used to remove rows of data from a table.


2.3.1 Data Definition Language (DDL)
DDL commands are used to define and manage the structure of the database. They include commands for creating, altering, and dropping database objects such as tables, indexes, and views.

CREATE: Used to create a new database object (e.g., table, index).
ALTER: Used to modify an existing database object (e.g., add or drop columns).
DROP: Used to delete an existing database object (e.g., table, index).
TRUNCATE: Used to delete all rows from a table without removing the table itself.
RENAME: Used to rename an existing database object (e.g., table, column).
COMMENT: Used to add comments to database objects (e.g., tables, columns).
CREATE INDEX: Used to create an index on a table to improve query performance.
DROP INDEX: Used to delete an existing index from a table.
CREATE VIEW: Used to create a virtual table based on the result of a query.
DROP VIEW: Used to delete an existing view from the database.
CREATE TABLE: Used to create a new table in the database.
ALTER TABLE: Used to modify the structure of an existing table (e.g., add or drop columns).
DROP TABLE: Used to delete an existing table from the database.

title: Course Structure
text:
Textbooks
The textbook for this course is just a supplement to the lectures and labs. The main resources for this course are the lecture notes, lab materials, and the course website. However, the following textbooks are recommended for additional reading:

Business Analytics by Camm, Cochran, Fry, Ohlmann, Anderson & Sweeney, 2024, 5th Edition.
Advanced Analytics with Power BI and R by Dr.¬†Leila Etaati, 2020.

title: Course Structure
text:
Assessment
The assessment for this unit is designed to evaluate your understanding of the course material and your ability to apply the concepts learned in practical scenarios. The assessment consists of the following components: - Quizzes: There will be a series of quizzes throughout the semester to test your understanding of the material covered in the lectures and readings. These quizzes will be conducted online and will consist of multiple-choice questions, short answer questions, and problem-solving exercises. The quizzes will be timed and will be available for a limited period. - Individual Assignments: You will be required to complete a series of individual assignments that will involve applying the concepts learned in the course to real-world scenarios. These assignments will require you to analyze data, interpret results, and present your findings in a clear and concise manner. The assignments will be submitted online and will be graded based on the quality of your analysis and presentation. - Group Project: You will be required to work in groups to complete a project that involves analyzing a dataset and presenting your findings. The project will require you to apply the concepts learned in the course to a real-world problem and will involve data collection, analysis, and presentation. The project will be graded based on the quality of your analysis, the effectiveness of your presentation, and your ability to work as a team. - Final Exam: The final exam will be a comprehensive assessment of the material covered in the course. The exam will consist of multiple-choice questions, short answer questions, and problem-solving exercises. The exam will be conducted in person and will be timed.

title: Course Structure
text:
Communication
All lecture notes, assignment instructions, an up-to-date schedule, and other course materials may be found on the course website or moodle page.
I will regularly send course announcements via Ed discussion board, make sure to check one or the other of these regularly. It is your responsibility to stay informed about the course progress and any changes to the schedule.

title: Course Structure
text:
Where to get help

If you have a question during lecture or tutorial, feel free to ask your teaching team or post your question in the discussion board. There are likely other students with the same question, and it is helpful to have the answer available to everyone.
The teaching team is here to help you be successful in the course. You are encouraged to attend the designated consultation hours to ask questions about the course content and assignments. Those consultation hours are available every day except weekend!
Outside of class and office hours, any general questions about course content or assignments should be posted on the Ed discussion board here. Please check whether your question has already been answered before posting. Please help each others by answering other questions, you will notice that you learn a lot by posting/responding to others. Do not expect the teaching team to answer questions that are posted during the weekend in the discussion board.
Emails should be reserved for personal questions that are not appropriate to be discuss in the forum. Please include ‚ÄúETF2121/5912‚Äù in the email subject line. Response time may be slower for emails with 24 hours being the maximum response time except weekend.

title: Course Structure
text:
Lectures and tutorials
Our goal in both lectures and labs is to encourage maximum interaction. As your instructor, I will introduce you to new tools and techniques, but it‚Äôs up to you to apply them effectively. Coding is best learned through practice, so much of our coursework will involve hands-on coding tasks. Each session will include various activities and assignments designed to enhance your skills.
Attendance and active participation in both lectures and tutorials are expected. Attending lectures and tutorials in person will provide the best learning experience. Some lectures will feature application exercises and periodic activities to foster a supportive learning community. These activities will be brief and enjoyable, aimed at strengthening connections among classmates throughout the semester.

Exams
Final exam. The exam will be held during the exam period, and it will be a closed-book exam with 5 pieces of A4 paper (10 pages) of handwritten/typed notes allowed. It is a supervised exam, and you will not be allowed to access the internet.


Software
All software used in this course can be downloaded for free. However, Power BI will not be available for Mac users, so I would encourage you to access it via MOVE. Please refer to this instruction.


Late work submission policy
Assignment deadlines are set to facilitate your progression through the course content and to enable timely feedback from the teaching team. I understand that unforeseen circumstances may occasionally arise, hindering your ability to meet a deadline. In such cases, you can request an extension through the Monash extension unit for extenuating circumstances. Please note that I do not grant individual approvals for late submissions, and requests should solely be made through the Monash extension unit.

There will be a 10% deduction for each 24-hour period the assignment is late.
If you submit an assessment task more than seven days after the due date, you‚Äôll receive a mark of zero and you won‚Äôt get any feedback.
Strictly no late submission without approval.
I will not reply to any email related to request on late submission.

title: 2¬† Introduction to R
text:
2.1 What is R?
R is a programming language and free software environment for statistical computing and graphics supported by the R Foundation for Statistical Computing. The R language is widely used among statisticians and data miners for developing statistical software and data analysis.

title: 2¬† Introduction to R
text:
2.2 Why R?

R is open-source and free
R is a powerful tool for data analysis
R has a large and active community
R has a large number of packages for data analysis
R is a great tool for reproducible research

title: 2¬† Introduction to R
text:
2.3 Posit (RStudio Desktop)
Posit (formerly RStudio) is an integrated development environment (IDE) for R. It includes a console, syntax-highlighting editor that supports direct code execution, as well as plotting (displaying graphs), history, debugging and workspace management tools.






‚ÄúR vs.¬†RStudio‚Äù



R is the programming language, while RStudio (now Posit) is an IDE that makes it easier to write and run R code. You can use R without RStudio, but RStudio provides a user-friendly interface and additional features that make working with R more efficient.

title: Power BI
text:
Why Power BI?
Power BI is a powerful business intelligence tool that can handle large datasets and perform complex calculations quickly. It can connect to a wide variety of data sources, including databases, cloud services, and Excel files. The user-friendly interface allows users to create interactive reports and dashboards with ease. Additionally, Power BI enables the creation of custom visualizations and reports using DAX (Data Analysis Expressions) and M (Power Query Formula Language). With built-in collaboration features, users can easily share reports and dashboards with others, making it an ideal choice for organizations looking to enhance their data analysis capabilities.

title: Power BI
text:
Power BI vs.¬†Excel
Power BI and Excel are both powerful tools for data analysis, but they serve different purposes and have different strengths. Here are some key differences:

Data Handling: Power BI is designed to handle large datasets and can connect to a wide variety of data sources, while Excel is more suited for smaller datasets and manual data entry.
Data Visualization: Power BI offers a wide range of interactive visualizations and dashboards, while Excel has more limited charting capabilities.
Collaboration: Power BI allows for easy sharing and collaboration on reports and dashboards, while Excel requires more manual effort to share files.
Data Modeling: Power BI has advanced data modeling capabilities, including relationships between tables and DAX calculations, while Excel is more focused on spreadsheet calculations.
Real-time Data: Power BI can connect to real-time data sources, allowing for up-to-date reporting, while Excel requires manual updates.
Cost: Power BI has a subscription-based pricing model, while Excel is typically purchased as part of the Microsoft Office suite.




Power BI vs Excel

title: Power BI
text:
Power BI vs.¬†Tableau
Power BI and Tableau are both powerful data visualization tools, but they have some key differences:

Ease of Use: Power BI is generally considered more user-friendly, especially for those already familiar with Microsoft products. Tableau has a steeper learning curve but offers more advanced features for experienced users.
Data Handling: Power BI is better suited for handling large datasets and can connect to a wider variety of data sources, while Tableau is more focused on visualizations and may struggle with very large datasets.
Cost: Power BI is typically more affordable, with a subscription-based pricing model, while Tableau can be more expensive, especially for larger teams.
Collaboration: Power BI has built-in collaboration features that make it easy to share reports and dashboards, while Tableau requires more manual effort to share visualizations.
Customization: Tableau offers more customization options for visualizations, while Power BI has a more standardized set of visualizations.
Integration: Power BI integrates seamlessly with other Microsoft products, while Tableau has a wider range of third-party integrations.
Community and Support: Both tools have strong user communities and support resources, but Power BI has a larger user base due to its integration with Microsoft products.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.6 What is the relationship between SQL vs.¬†RDBMS?
text:
1.6 What is the relationship between SQL vs.¬†RDBMS?
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases. It is the standard language for interacting with a RDBMS. SQL allows users to create, read, update, and delete data in a database. A RDBMS is the software that implements the database and provides the interface for users to interact with it using SQL.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.4 Data Query Language (DQL)
DQL commands are used to query and retrieve data from the database. The main DQL command is: - SELECT: Used to retrieve data from one or more tables in the database. - WHERE: Used to filter the results of a query based on specified conditions. - ORDER BY: Used to sort the results of a query in ascending or descending order - GROUP BY: Used to group the results of a query based on specified columns. - HAVING: Used to filter the results of a grouped query based on specified conditions - JOIN: Used to combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column between them. - UNION: Used to combine the results of two or more SELECT queries into a single result set. - DISTINCT: Used to retrieve unique values from a column, eliminating duplicate values. - LIMIT: Used to limit the number of rows returned by a query.
All these keywords will be explained in the next sections. üîÆ

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.5 Connecting to Oracle Database
For easy access and start, freesql is a free online SQL editor by Oracle that allows you to practice SQL queries without the need to install any software. You can sign up for a free account and start writing SQL queries right away.

2.5.1 How to sign up

Go to freesql.com.
Click on the ‚ÄúSign Up‚Äù button in the top right corner of the page.
Fill in the required information, including your name, email address, and password.
Click on the ‚ÄúCreate Account‚Äù button to complete the sign-up process.
Once you have created your account, you can log in to the platform and start using the SQL editor.



2.5.2 How to use FreeSQL

After logging in, you will be taken to the SQL editor page.
You can start writing SQL queries in the editor window.
To execute a query, click on the ‚ÄúRun‚Äù button or press ‚ÄúCtrl + Enter‚Äù on your keyboard.
The results of the query will be displayed in the results window
You can save your queries for future use by clicking on the ‚ÄúSave‚Äù button.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text: 3.1 SELECT Statement

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
text: 2.1 Table Creation

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.2 Inserting Data
To insert data into a table, you can use the INSERT INTO statement. Here is an example of how to insert a new employee into the Employees table:
INSERT INTO Employees (EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, HireDate)
VALUES (1, 'John', 'Doe', '2022-01-15');

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.4 Updating Data
To update existing data in a table, you can use the UPDATE statement. Here is an example of how to update the last name of an employee in the Employees table:
UPDATE Employees
SET LastName = 'Smith'
WHERE EmployeeID = 1;

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.5 Deleting Data
To delete data from a table, you can use the DELETE statement. Here is an example of how to delete an employee from the Employees table:
DELETE FROM Employees
WHERE EmployeeID = 1;

2.5.0.1 Exercises

Create a table called Departments with columns for DepartmentID, DepartmentName, and Location.

CREATE TABLE Departments (
    DepartmentID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    DepartmentName VARCHAR(100),
    Location VARCHAR(100)
);

Insert three departments into the Departments table with appropriate values.

INSERT INTO Departments (DepartmentID, DepartmentName, Location)
VALUES
(1, 'Human Resources', 'Sydney'),
(2, 'Finance', 'Melbourne'),
(3, 'IT', 'Brisbane');

Write a query to select all departments located in ‚ÄòMelbourne‚Äô.

SELECT * FROM Departments
WHERE Location = 'Melbourne';

Update the location of department to ‚ÄòQueensland‚Äô.

UPDATE Departments
SET Location = 'Queensland'
WHERE DepartmentID = 3;

Delete a department with a specific DepartmentID.

DELETE FROM Departments
WHERE DepartmentID = 2;

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.1.1 Creating a Table
To create a table in SQL, you can use the CREATE TABLE statement. Here is an example of how to create a simple table called Employees with columns for EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, and HireDate:
CREATE TABLE Employees (
    EmployeeID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    FirstName VARCHAR(50),
    LastName VARCHAR(50),
    HireDate DATE
);


2.1.2 Inserting Data
To insert data into a table, you can use the INSERT INTO statement. Here is an example of how to insert a new employee into the Employees table:
INSERT INTO Employees (EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, HireDate)
VALUES (1, 'John', 'Doe', '2022-01-15');


2.1.3 Querying Data
To retrieve data from a table, you can use the SELECT statement. Here is an example of how to select all columns from the Employees table:
SELECT * FROM Employees;


2.1.4 Updating Data
To update existing data in a table, you can use the UPDATE statement. Here is an example of how to update the last name of an employee in the Employees table:
UPDATE Employees
SET LastName = 'Smith'
WHERE EmployeeID = 1;


2.1.5 Deleting Data
To delete data from a table, you can use the DELETE statement. Here is an example of how to delete an employee from the Employees table:
DELETE FROM Employees
WHERE EmployeeID = 1;

2.1.5.1 Exercises

Create a table called Departments with columns for DepartmentID, DepartmentName, and Location.

CREATE TABLE Departments (
    DepartmentID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    DepartmentName VARCHAR(100),
    Location VARCHAR(100)
);

Insert three departments into the Departments table with appropriate values.

INSERT INTO Departments (DepartmentID, DepartmentName, Location)
VALUES
(1, 'Human Resources', 'Sydney'),
(2, 'Finance', 'Melbourne'),
(3, 'IT', 'Brisbane');

Write a query to select all departments located in ‚ÄòMelbourne‚Äô.

SELECT * FROM Departments
WHERE Location = 'Melbourne';

Update the location of department to ‚ÄòQueensland‚Äô.

UPDATE Departments
SET Location = 'Queensland'
WHERE DepartmentID = 3;

Delete a department with a specific DepartmentID.

DELETE FROM Departments
WHERE DepartmentID = 2;
Now, you know how to create table in SQL and perform basic operations like inserting, querying, updating, and deleting data! But, you will hardly use these commands as a data analyst. The most important command for you is the data querying and data manipulation commands which we will cover in the next sections.

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
section: 2.2 SQL for Data Querying and Manipulation
text:
2.2 SQL for Data Querying and Manipulation
SQL is a powerful language for querying and manipulating data in relational databases. As a data analyst, you will frequently use SQL to extract insights from data stored in databases. In this section, we will cover some of the most commonly used SQL commands for data querying and manipulation.

2.2.1 Selecting Data
The SELECT statement is used to retrieve data from a database. You can specify the columns you want to retrieve and the table from which to retrieve the data. The syntax for the SELECT statement is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name;
Here is an example of how to select specific columns from a table called Employees:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate
FROM Employees;


2.2.2 Filtering Data
The WHERE clause is used to filter the results based on a specified condition. Here is an example of how to select employees who were hired after January 1, 2020:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate
FROM Employees
WHERE HireDate > '2020-01-01';


2.2.3 Sorting Data
The ORDER BY clause is used to sort the results in ascending or descending order. Here is an example of how to select employees and sort them by their last name in ascending order:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate
FROM Employees
ORDER BY LastName ASC;
-- or in descending order
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate
FROM Employees
ORDER BY LastName DESC;


2.2.4 Distinct Values
The DISTINCT keyword is used to retrieve unique values from a column. Here is an example of how to select distinct job titles from a table called Jobs:
SELECT DISTINCT JobTitle
FROM Jobs;


2.2.5 Multiple Conditions
You can use logical operators such as AND, OR, and NOT to combine multiple conditions in the WHERE clause. The general syntax for using multiple conditions is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE condition1 AND|OR condition2;
Here is an example of how to select employees who were hired after January 1, 2020, and have a salary greater than 50000:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE HireDate > '2020-01-01' AND Salary > 50000;
Or you can use OR operator as below:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE HireDate > '2020-01-01' OR Salary > 50000;
This SQL selects the FirstName, LastName, HireDate, and Salary of employees from the Employees table where the HireDate is after January 1, 2020, or the Salary is greater than 50000.
The NOT operator can be used to exclude certain records. Here is an example of how to select employees who do not work in the department with ID 3:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, DepartmentID
FROM Employees
WHERE NOT DepartmentID = 3;

2.2.5.1 Exercises

Write a query to select all employees who work in the ‚ÄòIT‚Äô department.
Write a query to select distinct job titles from the Jobs table.
Write a query to select employees with a salary between 40000 and 80000.







Solutions





-- 1. Employees in 'IT' department
SELECT FirstName, LastName, DepartmentID
FROM Employees
WHERE DepartmentID = (SELECT DepartmentID FROM Departments WHERE DepartmentName = 'IT');

-- 2. Distinct job titles from Jobs table
SELECT DISTINCT JobTitle
FROM Jobs;

-- 3. Employees with salary between 40000 and 80000
SELECT FirstName, LastName, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary BETWEEN 40000 AND 80000;






2.2.6 Aggregating Data
SQL provides several aggregate functions that allow you to perform calculations on a set of values. Some commonly used aggregate functions include COUNT(), SUM(), AVG(), MIN(), and MAX(). Here is an example of how to count the number of employees in the Employees table:
SELECT COUNT(*) AS NumberOfEmployees
FROM Employees;
This SQL selects the total number of employees from the Employees table and labels the result as NumberOfEmployees. * means all rows.
-- Example of SUM function
SELECT SUM(Salary) AS TotalSalary
FROM Employees;
This SQL selects the total sum of the Salary column from the Employees table and labels the result as TotalSalary.
-- Example of AVG function
SELECT AVG(Salary) AS AverageSalary
FROM Employees;
This SQL selects the average value of the Salary column from the Employees table and labels the result as AverageSalary.
-- Example of MIN and MAX functions
SELECT MIN(Salary) AS MinimumSalary, MAX(Salary) AS MaximumSalary
FROM Employees;
This SQL selects the minimum and maximum values of the Salary column from the Employees table and labels the results as MinimumSalary and MaximumSalary, respectively.

2.2.6.1 Exercises

Write a query to select all employees who were hired in the year 2021.
Write a query to select distinct locations from the Departments table.
Write a query to count the total number of employees.
Write a query to find the average salary of employees in the Employees table.
Write a query to select employees and sort them by their hire date in descending order.
Write a query to find the maximum and minimum hire dates from the Employees table.
Write a query to count the number of distinct job titles in the Jobs table.







Solutions





-- 1. Employees hired in 2021
SELECT *
FROM Employees
WHERE YEAR(HireDate) = 2021;

-- 2. Distinct locations from Departments table
SELECT DISTINCT Location
FROM Departments;

-- 3. Count number of employees in each department
SELECT COUNT(*) AS TotalEmployees
FROM Employees;

-- 4. Average salary of employees
SELECT AVG(Salary) AS AverageSalary
FROM Employees;

-- 5. Employees sorted by hire date in descending order
SELECT *
FROM Employees
ORDER BY HireDate DESC;

-- 6. Maximum and minimum hire dates
SELECT MIN(HireDate) AS MinimumHireDate, MAX(HireDate) AS MaximumHire
FROM Employees;

-- 7. Count of distinct job titles in Jobs table
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT JobTitle) AS NumberOfJobTitles
FROM Jobs;






2.2.7 WHERE Clause
The WHERE clause is used to filter records that meet a certain condition. It can be used with various comparison operators such as =, !=, <, >, <=, >=, and logical operators like AND, OR, and NOT. The general syntax for the WHERE clause is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;
Here is an example of how to use the WHERE clause to select employees with a salary greater than 50000:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary > 50000;
This SQL selects the FirstName, LastName, and Salary of employees from the Employees table where the Salary is greater than 50000.

2.2.7.1 Exercises

Write a query to select employees who were hired before January 1, 2020.
Write a query to select employees with the job title ‚ÄòManager‚Äô and a salary greater than 60000.
Write a query to select employees who work in the ‚ÄòIT‚Äô department or have a salary less than 40000.







Solutions





-- 1. Employees hired before January 1, 2020
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate
FROM Employees
WHERE HireDate < '2020-01-01';

-- 2. Employees with job title 'Manager' and salary greater than 60000
SELECT FirstName, LastName, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE JobTitle = 'Manager' AND Salary > 60000;

-- 3. Employees in 'IT' department or salary less than 40000
SELECT FirstName, LastName, DepartmentID, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE DepartmentID = (SELECT DepartmentID FROM Departments WHERE DepartmentName = 'IT') OR Salary < 40000;






2.2.8 GROUP BY Clause
The GROUP BY clause is used to group rows that have the same values in specified columns into summary rows. It is often used with aggregate functions to perform calculations on each group of data. The general syntax for the GROUP BY clause is as follows:
SELECT column1, aggregate_function(column2)
FROM table_name
GROUP BY column1;
Here is an example of how to use the GROUP BY clause to count the number of employees in each department:
SELECT DepartmentID, COUNT(*) AS NumberOfEmployees
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID;
This SQL selects the DepartmentID and counts the number of employees in each department from the Employees table, grouping the results by DepartmentID and labeling the count as NumberOfEmployees.

2.2.8.1 Exercises

Write a query to find the total salary for each department.
Write a query to count the number of employees in each job title.
Write a query to find the average hire date for each department.







Solutions





-- 1. Total salary for each department
SELECT DepartmentID, SUM(Salary) AS TotalSalary
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID;

-- 2. Count of employees in each job title
SELECT JobTitle, COUNT(*) AS NumberOfEmployees
FROM Employees
GROUP BY JobTitle;

-- 3. Average hire date for each department
SELECT DepartmentID, AVG(HireDate) AS AverageHireDate
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID;






2.2.9 HAVING Clause
The HAVING clause is used to filter records that meet a certain condition after the GROUP BY clause has been applied. It is similar to the WHERE clause, but it is used for aggregated data. The general syntax for the HAVING clause is as follows:
SELECT column1, aggregate_function(column2)
FROM table_name
GROUP BY column1
HAVING condition;
Here is an example of how to use the HAVING clause to filter departments with more than 5 employees:
SELECT DepartmentID, COUNT(*) AS NumberOfEmployees
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID
HAVING COUNT(*) > 5;
This SQL selects the DepartmentID and counts the number of employees in each department from the Employees table, grouping the results by DepartmentID and filtering to include only those departments with more than 5 employees.

2.2.9.1 Exercises

Write a query to find departments with a total salary greater than 200000.
Write a query to find job titles with more than 10 employees.
Write a query to find departments with an average hire date before 2021.







Solutions





-- 1. Departments with total salary greater than 200000
SELECT DepartmentID, SUM(Salary) AS TotalSalary
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID
HAVING SUM(Salary) > 200000;

-- 2. Job titles with more than 10 employees
SELECT JobTitle, COUNT(*) AS NumberOfEmployees
FROM Employees
GROUP BY JobTitle
HAVING COUNT(*) > 10;

-- 3. Departments with average hire date before 2021
SELECT DepartmentID, AVG(HireDate) AS AverageHireDate
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID
HAVING AVG(HireDate) < '2021-01-01';









Confusion between WHERE and HAVING Clause‚Äù



The WHERE clause is used to filter rows before any grouping is done, while the HAVING clause is used to filter groups after the GROUP BY clause has been applied. Use WHERE for individual row conditions and HAVING for aggregated data conditions.





2.2.10 NULL Values
In SQL, NULL represents a missing or unknown value. It is important to handle NULL values properly when querying data. You can use the IS NULL and IS NOT NULL operators to check for NULL values in a column. The general syntax for checking NULL values is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name IS NULL|IS NOT NULL;
Here is an example of how to select employees with a NULL value in the ManagerID column:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, ManagerID
FROM Employees
WHERE ManagerID IS NULL;

2.2.10.1 Exercises

Write a query to select employees with a NULL value in the HireDate column.
Write a query to select employees with a non-NULL value in the Salary column.







Solutions





-- 1. Employees with NULL HireDate
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate
FROM Employees
WHERE HireDate IS NULL;

-- 2. Employees with non-NULL Salary
SELECT FirstName, LastName, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary IS NOT NULL;






2.2.11 LIMIT Clause
The LIMIT clause is used to specify the maximum number of records to return in the result set. It is useful when you want to retrieve a subset of data from a larger dataset. The general syntax for the LIMIT clause is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
LIMIT number_of_records;
Here is an example of how to use the LIMIT clause to select the first 10 employees from the Employees table:
SELECT *
FROM Employees
LIMIT 10;






Note on SQL Dialects



Not all SQL databases support the LIMIT clause. For example, in Microsoft SQL Server, you would use the SELECT TOP keyword instead. Use AI to check the syntax for your specific database system.



2.2.11.1 Exercises

Write a query to select the first 5 departments from the Departments table.
Write a query to select the first 3 employees with the highest salaries.







Solutions





-- 1. First 5 departments
SELECT *  
FROM Departments
LIMIT 5;

-- 2. First 3 employees with highest salaries
SELECT *
FROM Employees
ORDER BY Salary DESC
LIMIT 3;






2.2.12 LIKE Operator
The LIKE operator is used in the WHERE clause to search for a specified pattern in a column. It is often used with wildcard characters such as % (which represents zero or more characters) and _ (which represents a single character). The general syntax for the LIKE operator is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name LIKE pattern;
Here is an example of how to use the LIKE operator to select employees whose last name starts with ‚ÄòS‚Äô:
SELECT FirstName, LastName
FROM Employees
WHERE LastName LIKE 'S%';

2.2.12.1 Exercises

Write a query to select employees whose first name ends with ‚Äòn‚Äô.
Write a query to select employees whose last name contains ‚Äòar‚Äô.
Write a query to select employees whose first name has ‚Äòa‚Äô as the last letter.







Solutions





-- 1. Employees whose first name ends with 'n'
SELECT FirstName, LastName
FROM Employees
WHERE FirstName LIKE '%n';

-- 2. Employees whose last name contains 'ar'
SELECT FirstName, LastName
FROM Employees
WHERE LastName LIKE '%ar%';

-- 3. Employees whose first name has 'a' as the last letter
SELECT FirstName, LastName
FROM Employees
WHERE FirstName LIKE '%a';






2.2.13 IN Operator
The IN operator is used in the WHERE clause to filter records based on a list of specified values. It allows you to specify multiple values in a WHERE clause, making it easier to filter data. The general syntax for the IN operator is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name IN (value1, value2, ...);
Here is an example of how to use the IN operator to select employees who work in departments with IDs 1, 2, or 3:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, DepartmentID
FROM Employees
WHERE DepartmentID IN (1, 2, 3);

2.2.13.1 Exercises

Write a query to select employees who have the job titles ‚ÄòManager‚Äô, ‚ÄòAnalyst‚Äô, or ‚ÄòDeveloper‚Äô.
Write a query to select departments located in ‚ÄòSydney‚Äô, ‚ÄòMelbourne‚Äô, or ‚ÄòBrisbane‚Äô.







Solutions





-- 1. Employees with job titles 'Manager', 'Analyst', or 'Developer'
SELECT FirstName, LastName, JobTitle
FROM Employees
WHERE JobTitle IN ('Manager', 'Analyst', 'Developer');

-- 2. Departments located in 'Sydney', 'Melbourne', or 'Brisbane'
SELECT *
FROM Departments
WHERE Location IN ('Sydney', 'Melbourne', 'Brisbane');






2.2.14 BETWEEN Operator
The BETWEEN operator is used in the WHERE clause to filter records within a specified range. It is inclusive, meaning it includes the boundary values. The general syntax for the BETWEEN operator is as follows:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name BETWEEN value1 AND value2;
Here is an example of how to use the BETWEEN operator to select employees with salaries between 40000 and 80000:
SELECT FirstName, LastName, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary BETWEEN 40000 AND 80000;

2.2.14.1 Exercises

Write a query to select employees hired between January 1, 2020, and December 31, 2021.
Write a query to select departments with IDs between 2 and 5.







Solutions





-- 1. Employees hired between January 1, 2020, and December 31
SELECT FirstName, LastName, HireDate
FROM Employees
WHERE HireDate BETWEEN '2020-01-01' AND '2021-12-
31';

-- 2. Departments with IDs between 2 and 5
SELECT *
FROM Departments
WHERE DepartmentID BETWEEN 2 AND 5;






2.2.15 Aliases
Aliases are used to give a table or a column a temporary name. This can make your SQL queries easier to read and understand. You can create an alias using the AS keyword. The general syntax for creating an alias is as follows:
SELECT column_name AS alias_name
FROM table_name AS alias_name;
Here is an example of how to use aliases to rename columns in the result set:
SELECT FirstName AS First_Name, LastName AS Last_Name
FROM Employees AS E;
This SQL selects the FirstName and LastName columns from the Employees table, renaming them as First_Name and Last_Name in the result set. The Employees table is also given an alias of E for easier reference.

2.2.15.1 Exercises

Write a query to select the DepartmentName column from the Departments table and rename it as Dept_Name.
Write a query to select the FirstName and LastName columns from the Employees table and rename them as FName and LName, respectively.







Solutions





-- 1. Select DepartmentName and rename as Dept_Name
SELECT DepartmentName AS Dept_Name
FROM Departments;

-- 2. Select FirstName and LastName and rename as FName and LName
SELECT FirstName AS FName, LastName AS LName
FROM Employees;

title: 3¬† Advanced SQL
text:
3.1 Joins
Joins are used to combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column between them. Here are some common types of joins:

title: 3¬† Advanced SQL
text:
3.1.1 INNER JOIN
Returns records that have matching values in both tables.
SELECT a.column1, b.column2
FROM tableA a
INNER JOIN tableB b ON a.common_column = b.common_column;
Example: Select the names of employees along with their department names using an INNER JOIN.
SELECT e.Name, d.DepartmentName
FROM Employees e
INNER JOIN Departments d ON e.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID;
Result:



Name
DepartmentName




Alice
HR


Bob
IT





3.1.2 LEFT JOIN (or LEFT OUTER JOIN)
Returns all records from the left table, and the matched records from the right table. If there is no match, NULL values are returned for columns from the right table.
SELECT a.column1, b.column2
FROM tableA a
LEFT JOIN tableB b 
ON a.common_column = b.common_column;
Example: Select the names of employees along with their department names using a LEFT JOIN.
SELECT e.Name, d.DepartmentName
FROM Employees e
LEFT JOIN Departments d ON e.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID;
Result:



Name
DepartmentName




Alice
HR


Bob
IT


Charlie
NULL




RIGHT JOIN (or RIGHT OUTER JOIN): Returns all records from the right table, and the matched records from the left table. If there is no match, NULL values are returned for columns from the left table.
SELECT a.column1, b.column2
FROM tableA a
RIGHT JOIN tableB b
ON a.common_column = b.common_column;
FULL JOIN (or FULL OUTER JOIN): Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right table. If there is no match, NULL values are returned for columns from the table without a match.
SELECT a.column1, b.column2
FROM tableA a
FULL JOIN tableB b
ON a.common_column = b.common_column;
SELF JOIN: A self join is a regular join but the table is joined with itself.
SELECT a.column1, b.column2
FROM tableA a
INNER JOIN tableA b
ON a.common_column = b.common_column;
Normally, it is used to compare rows within the same table.
UNION: Combines the result sets of two or more SELECT statements. It removes duplicate rows between the various SELECT statements.
SELECT column1, column2 FROM tableA
UNION
SELECT column1, column2 FROM tableB;
UNION ALL: Similar to UNION, but it includes duplicate rows.
SELECT column1, column2 FROM tableA
UNION ALL
SELECT column1, column2 FROM tableB;
The requirement for using UNION or UNION ALL is that the number of columns and their data types must match in all SELECT statements, even its order.

title: 3¬† Advanced SQL
text:
3.2 EXISTS and NOT EXISTS
The EXISTS operator is used to test for the existence of any record in a subquery. It returns TRUE if the subquery returns one or more records. The general syntax is as follows:
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE EXISTS (SELECT column_name FROM table_name WHERE condition);
The NOT EXISTS operator is used to test for the non-existence of any record in a subquery. It returns TRUE if the subquery returns no records. The general syntax is as follows:
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT column_name FROM table_name WHERE condition);
Example: Find all departments that have at least one employee.
SELECT d.DepartmentName
FROM Departments d
WHERE EXISTS (
    SELECT 1
    FROM Employees e
    WHERE e.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID
);
Result:



DepartmentName




HR


IT



Example: Find all departments that do not have any employees.
SELECT d.DepartmentName
FROM Departments d
WHERE NOT EXISTS (
    SELECT 1
    FROM Employees e
    WHERE e.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID
);
Result:



DepartmentName




Finance

title: 3¬† Advanced SQL
text:
3.3 CASE Statements
The CASE statement is used to create conditional logic in SQL queries. It allows you to return different values based on specified conditions. The general syntax is as follows:
SELECT column1,
       CASE
           WHEN condition1 THEN result1
           WHEN condition2 THEN result2
           ELSE result3
       END AS alias_name
FROM table_name;
Example: Use a CASE statement to categorize employees based on their department.
SELECT e.Name,
       CASE
           WHEN e.DepartmentID = 1 THEN 'HR'
           WHEN e.DepartmentID = 2 THEN 'IT'
           ELSE 'Other'
       END AS DepartmentCategory
FROM Employees e;
Result:



Name
DepartmentCategory




Alice
HR


Bob
IT


Charlie
Other

title: 3¬† Advanced SQL
text:
3.4 Common Table Expressions (CTEs)
A Common Table Expression (CTE) is a temporary result set that you can reference within a SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement. CTEs are defined using the WITH clause. The general syntax is as follows:
WITH cte_name AS (
    SELECT column1, column2
    FROM table_name
    WHERE condition
)
SELECT *
FROM cte_name;
CTE is especially useful for breaking down complex queries into simpler parts, improving readability, and enabling recursion.
Example: Use a CTE to find the names of employees along with their department names.
WITH EmployeeDepartments AS (
    SELECT e.Name, d.DepartmentName
    FROM Employees e
    LEFT JOIN Departments d ON e.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID
)
SELECT *
FROM EmployeeDepartments;
Result:



Name
DepartmentName




Alice
HR


Bob
IT


Charlie
NULL

title: 3¬† Advanced SQL
text:
3.5 Window Functions
Window functions perform calculations across a set of table rows that are related to the current row. They are often used for ranking, running totals, moving averages, etc. The general syntax is as follows:
SELECT column1,
       window_function() OVER (PARTITION BY column2 ORDER BY column3) AS alias_name
FROM table_name;
Example: Use a window function to assign a row number to each employee within their department.
SELECT e.Name,
       ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY e.DepartmentID ORDER BY e.Name) AS Row
FROM Employees e;
Result:



Name
Row




Alice
1


Bob
1


Charlie
1



This assigns a row number to each employee within their respective departments, ordered by their names.
These advanced SQL concepts and techniques can help you write more efficient and powerful queries to manage and analyze your data.
